slides.Title: Introduction to NLP: Regular Expressions, Text Normalization, and Edit Distance
slides.Description: This chapter delves into fundamental tools and concepts in natural language processing, focusing on Regular Expressions, Text Normalization, and Edit Distance.

slides.Title: Regular Expressions
slides.Description: Regular expressions are sequences of characters used for pattern matching and string manipulation in text processing.

slides.Title: Components of Regular Expressions
slides.Description: Key components include Concatenation, Disjunction, Range, Kleene Star, Anchors, Counters, Precedence, Substitution, and Lookahead Assertions.

slides.Title: Text Normalization
slides.Description: Text normalization involves converting text into a more standardized form. This includes processes like tokenization, lemmatization, stemming, and sentence segmentation.

slides.Title: Tokenization in NLP
slides.Description: Tokenization is the task of breaking up text into individual tokens, which can be complex in languages like English with varied word separations and even more challenging in languages without spaces like Japanese.

slides.Title: Lemmatization and Stemming
slides.Description: Lemmatization involves finding the base or root form of a word, while stemming is a simpler process of removing word suffixes.

slides.Title: Edit Distance
slides.Description: Edit Distance measures the similarity between two strings based on the number of edits needed to transform one string into the other. Common edits include insertions, deletions, and substitutions.

slides.Title: Applications of Edit Distance
slides.Description: Edit distance is widely used in various NLP tasks, including spelling correction, speech recognition, and coreference resolution.

slides.Title: Dynamic Programming in Edit Distance
slides.Description: Dynamic programming is a method used to efficiently compute the minimum edit distance, providing a way to align two strings.

slides.Title: ELIZA: An Early Example of NLP
slides.Description: ELIZA is an early natural language processing system that used pattern matching to mimic conversation, serving as a historical example of the application of regular expressions in NLP.

slides.Title: Summary of Key Points
slides.Description: This chapter covered the essentials of regular expressions, text normalization tasks including tokenization and stemming, and the concept of edit distance in string comparison.
